Notes: The definition of "maintenance mode." Acquired by a buy-and-hold group. Extremely robust rent engine but the UI is ancient menu-driven legacy.
Very small team. Their "new" web version is essentially the old desktop database rendered in a browser. Modular and very specific to UK housing rules.
Recently acquired by Harris (another buy-and-hold giant). Standard for Town Councils. Very "grey screen" accounting feel. Unlikely to see major R&D.
Manages statutory burial registers. The law hasn't changed in 100 years
Link: so neither has the core logic. Pure database administration.

Notes: Driven entirely by NDTMS (govt) reporting requirements. Rigid workflow: "Form A -> Form B". Very secure
A dense "Daily Log" database. Prioritizes data capture over UX. Widely used by independent agencies who need to survive Ofsted audits.
Used by police/charities. A secure form-filling engine. Very quiet company
The "original" PropTech. Incredibly complex accounting back-end. Users tolerate the legacy UI because it handles service charge audits perfectly.
Classic on-premise style software (hosted or local). Feature-rich but button-heavy. Very difficult to migrate away from due to banking integrations.
The UK industry standard. They are slowly moving to cloud
Link: but the core product is a legacy compliance engine that dominates the market.

Notes: Refuses to be acquired. Maintains a heavy desktop client beloved by traditional solicitors who dislike browser-based apps. Very stable
A heavy scripting engine. You don't "configure" it; you "code" it. Interface is dated
Link: but flexibility keeps it in place. Now owned by Advanced but operates as legacy.

Notes: Time and File tracking for council lawyers. Very simple
Link: integrates with Outlook. Feels like a database wrapper for billing.

Notes: Handles complex union rulebooks (ballots
Link: grievances). The UI is functional and data-heavy. Upgrades are often just compliance patches.

Notes: A "thick client" database for headhunters. Very fast for data entry (keyboard shortcuts) but looks like a classic 2000s CRM. Publicly listed.
The "Microsoft Access" of the charity world. Simple tables
Link: simple reports. Used by Age UKs. Very little changes because it does exactly what is needed.

Notes: Self-configured database. You build the tables. Very popular with small charities. The "software" is just a shell for your data structure.
Used by public sector to track slip-and-trip claims. It is a digital ledger of incidents and reserves. Functional
Strictly for construction (job costing
Link: retentions). It is an accounting system first
Replacement Ease (1=Hard 5=Easy): case manager second. Very traditional "ERP" feel.

Notes: High-volume transaction processing. It runs "dunning" workflows (Letter 1
Link: Letter 2). The "case view" is just a window into the transaction log.

Notes: Notes
The absolute standard for Council legal teams. It is essentially an email and document wrapper that forces lawyers to file things correctly. Very "local government" feel.
Owned by a consortium of Local Authorities. It effectively rations social housing. A massive forms engine that dictates who gets a house and who doesn't.
If you run an apprenticeship college, you likely use this. It exists solely to generate the XML file the government demands for funding. Now owned by Volaris (buy-and-hold).
The engine behind the bailiff industry. Manages the workflow from court order to knocking on the door. Grimly efficient transaction processing.
Used by Citizens Advice and non-profits. Secure case recording for vulnerable people. It prioritizes data protection over usability. A joint venture with the charity sector.
The "back office" engine for estate agents who care about accounting more than marketing. Incredibly grey UI, but handles client money regulations perfectly.
The modern rival to RBS. Purpose-built for Parish Clerks who aren't accountants. It kills Excel spreadsheets but is very niche to the bottom tier of local gov.
An academic spin-out used by the NHS for depression/anxiety stats. It is a clinical tool designed by researchers, not UX designers. Pure functionality.
A "workflow factory" for property lawyers. It tracks the chain of a house sale. Users live inside it all day. Very dense, very prescriptive.
Aims for the cloud but carries a legacy soul. Popular with high-street firms who want a "secure" feeling system. A solid, reliable plodder.
ERP for people who sell nuts, bolts, and steel. It manages the "case" of a customer order through to the warehouse. Looks like Windows 95, works like a tank.
The database for hospices. It handles the specific complexity of "In Memory" donations that big US CRMs struggle with. Very loyal user base.
Used by niche trade bodies to track subscriptions. It is a glorified Rolodex with a billing engine. Rock solid, does not crash, does not change.
Tracks broken toilets and lightbulbs in hospitals/factories. It is a digital job-card system. Simple, rugged, and unpretentious.
Used by Members of Parliament to track constituent complaints. Highly sensitive data. It is the digital memory of a politician's office.
Tracks children's attendance and government funding hours. Critical for billing parents. A mix of complex funding calc and parent comms.
The aggressive challenger to the SIMS monopoly. Feature-rich, data-heavy, and widely used by Academy Chains. The UI is "everything at once".
Another Volaris acquisition. Predicts when boilers and roofs need replacing 30 years out. Pure data crunching for housing directors.
Used by clinics that can't afford the US giants (Epic/Cerner). It manages patient pathways in niche NHS depts. Very modular, very functional.
Software for skips and garbage trucks. Tracks the "case" of a bin from drop-off to landfill tax. Niche industrial logic.
